message_1: What is the chemical structure of a compound with the chemical formula C6H12O6, determined by Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy (MRS)?
message_2:
C6H12O6 is the molecular formula for glucose, a common monosaccharide. The chemical structure of glucose can be determined using Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy (NMR). 

The structure of glucose is as follows:

       HOCH2
         |
         C
         |
HO-C-H   C-OH
   |     |
   C-OH  C-OH
   |     |
   C-OH  C-OH
   |     |
   CH2OH  H

This is the structure of D-glucose in its linear form. In solution, glucose predominantly exists in its cyclic form, either as α-D-glucopyranose or β-D-glucopyranose. The cyclic form is formed by the reaction between the aldehyde group (C=O) at the first carbon and the hydroxyl group (OH) at the fifth carbon, forming a hemiacetal linkage and a six-membered ring structure.
